title: Evidence from Late Cretaceous-Paleogene volcanic rocks of the Kyrenia Range, northern Cyprus for the northern, active continental margin of the Southern Neotethys
abstract: Late Cretaceous felsic and latest Cretaceous-Paleogene basaltic volcanic rocks are exposed throughout the Kyrenia Range, N Cyprus. Field mapping of the key, well-exposed western range indicates that the felsic volcanics mainly crop out in the southerly, frontal part of the range, separated from the latest Cretaceous-Paleogene basaltic volcanics farther north by a thrust. New U-Pb zircon dating of the felsic volcanics indicates a primary age of c. 74.0 Ma (Late Campanian). The felsic volcanics are characterised by evolved compositions that were probably generated in an extensional subduction-related setting. Their relatively low Nb and Y but high Rb concentrations, together with characteristic Th/Ta ratios (6-20), suggest a mature continental arc setting. The latest Cretaceous-Paleogene basaltic volcanics have mainly within-plate chemical characteristics (in the east), although some have a subordinate subduction influence; e.g. negative Nb (in the west). Sr-Nd-Hf isotopic signatures (i.e. high positive εNd(t) and εHf(t) values) suggest derivation of the basalts from several OIB-like mantle sources, with probable involvement of a crustal (recycled) component (i.e. elevated Nb/Y ratios). Comparisons with SE Turkey, where Late Cretaceous arc-related granitic rocks are widely developed, suggest that the Kyrenia Range igneous rocks may have originated to the south of the Alanya metamorphic massif (N of Cyprus) and correlative continental units in SE Turkey. The latest Cretaceous-Paleogene basaltic volcanics in N Cyprus and SE Turkey (Maden Complex) are interpreted to represent incipient marginal basin formation, possibly in an oblique-convergent setting, prior to Miocene suturing with Arabia. In the light of alternatives, we infer genesis of the N Cyprus Late Cretaceous and Paleogene volcanic rocks related to stages in the development of the northerly active continental margin of the Southern Neotethys.

body_text.text: Continental margin magmatism is a key feature of subduction at convergent plate margins (Dewey, 1969; Şengör and Natal'in, 1996) . Information concerning the field relations, age, petrology and geochemistry are essential to understand the growth and demise of arcs, and are critical to reconstruct paleogeography and to test alternative tectonic hypotheses (e.g. Bowman et al., 2019; Tatsumi and Kogiso, 2003; Trehu et al., 1994) .

The Eastern Mediterranean region, situated between the North African-Arabian and Anatolian (Eurasian) plates, includes tectonically emplaced remnants of Neotethys that developed from the preceding Paleotethys farther north (e.g. Le Pichon, 1982; Robertson and Dixon, 1984; Şengör et al., 1984; Stampfli and Borel, 2002) . Much of the arc magmatism in the north, in the Pontides, of Jurassic-Eocene age ( Fig. 1 ), relates to long-lived northward subduction of the Northern Neotethys (İzmir-Ankara-Erzincan ocean) (Adamia et al., 1977; Dercourt et al., 1993; Rice et al., 2006; Ustaömer and Robertson, 1997) . Subduction of the Southern Neotethys resulted in both continental margin and oceanic magmatism that ranges, overall, from Late Cretaceous to Paleogene (Fig. 1) . Here, we focus on evidence of Late Cretaceous and Paleogene volcanism in the Kyrenia Range of northern Cyprus, representing the most westerly known occurrence of arc-type magmatism that can be related to subduction of the Southern Neotethys (Fig. 1) (Baroz, 1979 (Baroz, , 1980 Ducloz, 1972; Huang et al., 2007; Moore, 1960; Pearce, 1975; Robertson et al., 2012b; Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) .

Our specific objectives here are: (1) to understand the tectonostratigraphy of two, contrasting, felsic and basaltic volcanic units in relation to associated sedimentary units; (2) to determine the eruptive ages of both of the volcanic units directly, using geochronology. Previously, the volcanics were dated indirectly using microfossils within interbedded pelagic carbonates (Baroz, 1979; Robertson et al., 2012b) ; (3) to determine whether there is any petrological or geochemical variation (including isotopic variation) along the Kyrenia Range (c. 100 km) and, if so, the implications; (4) to infer the magmatic-tectonic setting of eruption, compared with the evidence of arc volcanism, especially in southeast Turkey; (5) to test alternative tectono-magmatic hypotheses bearing in mind that arc magmatism plays a key role in plate tectonic interpretations.

Rifting of the Southern Neotethys during Late Permian and Early-Middle Triassic was followed by continental break-up during the Late Triassic-Early Jurassic (Garfunkel, 1998; Robertson and Dixon, 1984; Robertson and Woodcock, 1979; Şengör and Yılmaz, 1981) . The Kyrenia Range then formed part of a carbonate platform that slowly subsided during Jurassic-Early Cretaceous in a passive margin setting (Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) . The carbonate platform was deformed and metamorphosed under greenschist facies during the Late Cretaceous, extensionally exhumed, and then unconformably overlain by basic extrusive igneous rocks of latest Cretaceous-Paleogene age (Figs. 2-3 ) (Baroz, 1979; Ducloz, 1972; Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) . In addition, felsic volcanics and tuffs are exposed as thrust slices at a low structural level in the south of the range (Figs. 2b, 3 ) (Robertson et al., 2012b) . These volcanic rocks have no exposed base and are directly overlain by a much larger thrust sheet that includes the mainly basic extrusive igneous rocks. Baroz (1979 Baroz ( , 1980 mapped the volcanic rocks and carried out petrographic and whole-rock chemical analysis of major elements. He reported the presence of a lower stratigraphic sequence of basalt, dolerite, trachybasalt, trachyandesite, dacite and rhyolitic tuff, and interpreted this as a bimodal basic-acidic calc-alkaline suite, related to a Late Maastrichtian volcanic arc. In contrast, the Paleogene volcanic assemblage was suggested to have erupted stratigraphically above in a post-collisional (intra-continental) strike-slip setting (Baroz, 1980) . However, a thrust was later mapped between the mainly felsic and mainly basic suites (Robertson et al., 2012b) , complicating this simple stratigraphy.

Chemical analysis of the Paleogene basaltic lavas, including immobile trace elements, initially suggested an alkaline, within-plate eruptive setting (Pearce, 1975) . Subsequent chemical analysis, Fig. 1 . Outline tectonic map of the Eastern Mediterranean region, including the main volcanic units mentioned in the text. The tectonic framework is modified after Robertson et al. (2012a) . Note the location of the Kyrenia Range in northern Cyprus (red box). Jurassic, Cretaceous and Eocene igneous rocks are shown in blue, red and yellow, respectively (see the text for literature sources). Fig. 2 . Successions shown two main thrust sheets exposed in the Kyrenia Range, northern Cyprus. (a) Simplified log of the succession in the largest thrust sheet including the latest Cretaceous-Paleogene volcanics (Melounda Formation); (b) Restored log of the small, dismembered frontal thrust sheets that exposes the Late Cretaceous felsic volcanics (Fourkovouno Formation) (data from Baroz, 1979 ; Robertson et al., 2012b and this study).

including some immobile elements, confirmed this mainly alkaline within-plate setting but also revealed some evidence of a subduction influence (e.g. negative Nb anomaly) (Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) . The Paleogene lavas were inferred by these authors to have erupted in a transtensional setting along the northern, active margin of the 'Troodos ocean'. Huang et al. (2007) carried out additional chemical analysis of the Paleogene basaltic lavas, mainly from the eastern and western Kyrenia Range, with emphasis on immobile elements, and proposed a Late Cretaceous-Paleogene backarc setting related to northward subduction. Robertson et al., 2012b) . Locations from which basalts were collected are numbered on the map, with small yellow boxes. Karpas Peninsula: 1-Balalan (Platanissos); Eastern Range: 2-Ağıllar (Mandres), 3-Çınarlı (Platani), 4-Mallıdağ (Melounda); Central Range: 5-Tirmen (Trypimeni), 6-Ergenekon (Agios Khariton), 7-Değirmenlik (Kythrea), 8-Arapköy (Klepini), 9-Beylerbeyi (Bellapais), 10-Boğaz (Bogaz), 11-Pınarbaşı (Krini), 12-İncesu (Motides), 13-Alevkaya Tepe (Kiparisso Vouno); Western Range: 14-Karşıyaka (Vasileia), 15-Selvilitepe (Fourkovouno), 16-Geçitköy (Panagra); (b) Geological map of the western Kyrenia Range, northern Cyprus made during this study (based on mapping by Baroz, 1979) . Locations of cross sections (AA', BB' and CC') are indicated. Note that the two contrasting, mainly felsic and mainly basaltic volcanic units are separated by a thrust fault (Robertson et al., 2012b ; this study; see Fig. 2 ).

The felsic rocks of the lowermost thrust sheet, known as the Fourkovouno (Selvilitepe) 2 Formation, up to 400 m thick, begin with marine water-lain felsic tuffs and subaqueous felsic debris-flow deposits and culminate in laterally discontinuous, thick-bedded to massive rhyolitic lava flows (Fig. 3) (Baroz, 1979; Huang et al., 2007; Moore, 1960; Robertson et al., 2012b) . The felsic rocks are locally cut by small (metre-sized) basaltic/doleritic intrusions (not studied). A Late Cretaceous age (Late Campanian) was suggested for the felsic lavas, based on sparse planktic foraminifera (Globotruncana sp.) that were recognised in a chalky interbed near the top of the succession (Baroz, 1979) .

The Late Cretaceous and Paleogene basaltic igneous rocks have been divided into two formations, namely the Maastrichtian Melounda (Mallıdağ) Formation and the Paleocene-Middle Eocene Ayios Nikolaos (Yamaçköy) Formation (Fig. 2a) .

The Melounda Formation, c. 300 m thick, unconformably overlies the exhumed Mesozoic platform carbonates of the Trypa (Tripa) Group or, in places, unmetamorphosed terrigenous turbidites of the Kiparisso Vouno (Alevkaya Tepe) Member of the Melounda Formation (Baroz, 1979; Robertson et al., 2012b; Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) . The basaltic lavas of the Melounda Formation are commonly intercalated with pinkish pelagic limestones ( Fig. 2a ). The succession locally includes lenticular, lithoclastic breccias and finer-grained clastic facies that were reworked from the underlying meta-platform carbonates ( Fig. 2a ) (Robertson et al., 2012b; Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) . Planktic foraminifera from pelagic carbonates between the lavas indicate a Late Maastrichtian age (Baroz, 1979; Robertson et al., 2012b) .

The overlying Ayios Nikolaos Formation, 300-400 m thick, comprises basaltic volcanics that are variably interbedded with pelagic carbonates. Calciturbidites, calcareous debris-flow deposits and carbonate-rock breccias appear above the lavas, towards the top of the overall succession (Baroz, 1979; Robertson and Woodcock, 1986; Robertson et al., 2012b Robertson et al., , 2014 (Fig. 2a ). Planktic foraminifera from pelagic carbonates that are interbedded with the lavas indicate a Late Paleocene to Mid-Eocene age range (Baroz, 1979; Robertson et al., 2012b) .

The Kyrenia Range is a complex thrust belt and therefore it was essential to remap the western Kyrenia Range, where felsic and basaltic volcanic rocks are exposed together (Baroz, 1979; Moore, 1960; Robertson et al., 2012b) . In addition, sedimentary logs were measured and correlated to produce a composite stratigraphy of the volcanogenic successions that are exposed in two superimposed thrust sheets.

Optical microscopy was carried out on the samples collected. For the felsic lithologies, 13 samples were studied from the western range. For the basaltic lithologies, we used a combination of our samples (n = 29) and also some that were previously collected for paleomagnetic study (n = 26) throughout the Kyrenia Range (Morris et al., 2015) .

Whole-rock major and trace element concentrations of the volcanic rocks were measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) on fused glass beads and pressed powder pellets at the School of GeoSciences, University of Edinburgh, using the well-known methods of Fitton et al. (1998) and Fitton and Godard (2004) . Accuracy and precision are typically c. 5%. For representative samples, additional trace and rare earth element (REE) analysis was carried out by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) at the ACME Analytical Laboratories, Vancouver. Trace element contents were determined from a LiBO 2 fusion by ICP-MS, using 5 g of sample pulp. Detection limits range between 0.01 and 0.1 ppm for trace and rare earth elements. The relative standard deviation for the REE is~5% and for all other trace elements is up to 10%, with quality control using international geostandards (see http:// acmelab.com).

In addition, Sr-Nd-Hf isotopic analysis was performed on a Neptune Plus multi-collector (MC)-ICP-MS at Wuhan SampleSolution Analytical Technology Co., Ltd., China, as reported by Li et al. (2012) . Whole procedural blanks were <100 pg for Sr, <50 pg for Nd and <50 pg for Hf. 87 Sr/ 86 Sr, 143 Nd/ 144 Nd and 176 Hf/ 177 Hf ratios were normalised to 86 Sr/ 88 Sr = 0.1194, 146 Nd/ 144 Nd = 0.7219 and 179 Hf/ 177 Hf = 0.7325, using the exponential law. Standard analysis yielded 87 Sr/ 86 Sr = 0.710240 ± 11 (2SD, n = 4) for NBS987, 143 Nd/ 144 Nd = 0.512440 ± 8 (2SD, n = 8) for GSB 04-3258-2015, and 176 Hf/ 177 Hf = 0.282224 ± 6 (2SD, n = 6) for Alfa Hf. In addition, USGS reference materials BCR-2 and RGM-2 were also analysed for Sr-Nd-Hf isotopes, and gave ratios of 0.705039 ± 8 and 0.704169 ± 11 for 87 Sr/ 86 Sr, 0.512644 ± 6 and 0.512808 ± 9 for 143 Nd/ 144 Nd and 0.282864 ± 6 and 0.283016 ± 7 for 176 Hf/ 177 Hf, which is within error of recommended values (Thirlwall, 1991; Weis et al., 2006 Weis et al., , 2007 . The analytical data for the major, trace and rare earth elements/isotope ratio of the felsic and basaltic volcanics are listed in the Supplementary Tables S1, S2, respectively.

In addition, two polished thin sections of basalt (no. 02 and 21) that contain relatively fresh feldspar and pyroxene crystals were selected for analysis of major elements using a Cameca SX100 electron microprobe at the School of GeoSciences, University of Edinburgh. Details of the analytical conditions and methods are given by Hayward (2011) and by Hartley and Thordarson (2013) . The accuracy of major element determinations is <± 1% of total value. Analytical data for feldspar and pyroxene are given in Supplementary Tables S3, S4, respectively. For dating, zircon crystals within 30-160 μm fraction were separated from crushed felsic tuffaceous rock and rhyolitic lava (no. 14-18, 14-19 and 14-20; c. 5 kg each). A Wilfley table, Frantz Isodynamic magnetic separator and a high-density solution (lithium polytungstate; 2.85 g/ ml) were used to aid separation. The zircon grains were randomly handpicked under a binocular microscope, mounted in epoxy resin and polished sufficiently to expose the centre of the grains. Internal structures were studied with a scanning electron microscope using cathodoluminescence (CL) at the School of GeoSciences, University of Edinburgh. U-Pb analysis was then performed using a Cameca IMS-1270 secondary ion mass spectrometer (SIMS) at the School of GeoSciences, University of Edinburgh, using the methods reported by Kelly et al. (2008) and Ustaömer et al. (2012) . Errors of the reported ages are ±1σ. Related geochronological plots were produced using ISOPLOT (Ludwig, 2012) . Analytical results are listed in the Supplementary Table S5 .

The felsic volcanics, mainly crop out in the western part of the Kyrenia Range within two thrust sheets (Figs. 3-4 ). The lower of these, which is relatively intact, extends from Geçitköy (Panagra) eastwards to Selvilitepe (Fourkovouno) ( Fig. 5a-e ). The second, structurally higher unit, comprises discontinuous exposures extending from north of Geçitköy, to southwest of Karsıyaka (Vasileia) and west of Alevkaya Tepe (Kiparisso Vouno) ( Fig. 5f-j) . Farther west, in the Kayalar (Orga) area ( Fig. 3a) , a small thrust slice exposes coarse-grained felsic tuff and a felsic debris-flow deposit. Small (tens of m-sized) outcrops of felsic volcanogenic rocks also occur farther east; e.g. northeast of Aşağı Dikmen (Kato Dikomon), between thrust sheets of Mesozoic meta-carbonate rocks (Baroz, 1979) . Small exposures are also intersliced with Late Cretaceous pelagic carbonates of the Melounda Formation to the north of Ergenekon (Agios Khariton) ( Fig. 3a ) (Robertson et al., 2012b) .

The local successions are restored as a lower thrust sheet and an upper thrust sheet. The succession in the lower thrust sheet, c. 90 m thick, begins with weakly-bedded, white felsic tuff (beds <0.5 m thick) (Fig. 5a , c-e), followed by thick layers of matrix-supported felsic brecciaconglomerate (c. 10 m thick) that we interpret as debris-flow deposits (Fig. 5a, c, e ). The succession passes upwards into massive, vitreous, rhyolitic lava flows, individually up to 10 m thick (Figs. 5a, Supplementary  Fig. S1 ). Localised normal grading; e.g. northeast of Geçitköy, indicates that the succession is the right way up, stratigraphically (Fig. 5a-b) . In places, steeply dipping, irregularly shaped basaltic or doleritic intrusions, up to 2 m across, cut the felsic layering (Figs. 5a, Supplementary  Fig. S1 ). Adjacent to these intrusions, poorly consolidated tuffaceous sediments have undergone contact metamorphism to form hard, dark grey, flint-like, recrystallised felsic rock (Robertson et al., 2012b) . There is no evidence of similar intrusions in the structurally overlying basalts, which is in keeping with the mapped tectonic contact between . Measured stratigraphic logs of partial successions in the felsic volcanics and structurally associated units. The structural lower unit (logs a-e) is relatively intact, whereas the higher unit (logs f-j) is characterised by thrust intercalations with the Trypa Group. the two units. The succession in the upper thrust sheet begins with greyish to greenish, tuffaceous matrix-supported conglomerates, including clasts of silicified rhyolite, chalk and basalt ( Supplementary  Fig. S1 ). The estimated thickness ranges from c. 40 m north of Geçitköy ( Fig. 5f ), to c. 80 m southwest of Karsıyaka ( Fig. 5g-h ), to 30 m west of the Alevkaya Tepe ( Fig. 5i-j) .

The contrasting field relations have facilitated mapping of the Late Cretaceous versus the Paleogene formations (Baroz, 1979; Hakyemez et al., 2000; Robertson et al., 2012b; Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) . In the far east of the Kyrenia Range, the Karpas Peninsula (Fig. 3a) , both pillowed and massive basalt are widely exposed near Balalan (Platanissos). Interpillow carbonate and lenticular interbeds of pelagic carbonate (<1 m thick) (Figs. 3a, Supplementary Fig. S2 ) contain Late Maastrichtian microfossils (Robertson et al., 2012b) . In the eastern range, basaltic rocks of the Melounda Formation contain abundant pelagic carbonate and are overlain by massive basalts of the Ayios Nikolaos Formation; i.e. from Ağıllar (Mandres) to Mallıdağ (Melounda) ( Fig. 3a ) (Baroz, 1979; Hakyemez et al., 2000; Robertson et al., 2012b; Robertson and Woodcock, 1986) . In the central range, pillow lava with interbedded pelagic carbonate of the Melounda Formation occurs in two settings. The first is directly above the Upper Cretaceous basal unconformity, with the meta-carbonate platform rock beneath; e.g. near Tirmen (Trypimeni). The second setting is as one (or several), small thrust sheets along the southern flank of the range; e.g. Değirmenlik (Kythrea), Boğaz (Bogaz) and southwest of Alevkaya Tepe (Figs. 3a, Supplementary Fig. S2 ). Basalt with some interbedded pelagic carbonate of the Ayios Nikolaos Formation is exposed higher in the succession (within a shear zone), near Tirmen, Arapköy (Klepini) and İncesu (Motides) (Baroz, 1979) . In the western range, basaltic lavas, interbedded with pelagic carbonates of the Melounda Formation, are exposed in a thrust sheet along the southern margin of the range; e.g. Geçitköy ( Fig. 3, Supplementary Fig. S2 ). Similar basaltic lavas with pelagic carbonates and local carbonate breccias are exposed along the northern margin of the range; e.g. near Karşıyaka and farther west (Baroz, 1979; Hakyemez et al., 2000; Robertson et al., 2012b) . In addition, basaltic lava interbedded with pelagic chalk of the Ayios Nikolaos Formation occurs higher in the succession (southward-younging) along the eastern side of Geçitköy road (Huang et al., 2007; Robertson et al., 2012b) .

In summary, the Late Maastrichtian basalts (Melounda Formation) are typically pillowed, forming repeated flows (individually up to c. 10 m thick), reaching a maximum of >90 m in the east (near Balalan). The lavas include pink pelagic carbonate as interstitial sediment and discontinuous layers. In contrast, the Paleogene basalts (Ayios Nikolaos Formation) are commonly massive, especially in the eastern range, where individual lava flows reach c. 45 m thick, with relatively few pelagic intercalations ( Supplementary Fig. S2 ). In the central and western ranges, thinner lava flows (<10 m) are intercalated with pelagic carbonates and reddish chert (formed by diagenetic replacement). During this work, we identified geochemical differences between the Late Cretaceous-Paleogene basaltic lavas of similar age along the fareastern, eastern, central and western Kyrenia Range (see below).

The felsic rocks are porphyritic, composed of quartz, plagioclase and sanidine, together with subordinate biotite and rare hornblende. Large sanidine crystals (0.3-1 mm) show simple twinning, whereas plagioclase commonly has lamellar twinning ( Supplementary Fig. S3 ). Biotite laths (0.3-0.8 mm in length) are preferentially orientated parallel to flow layering. Rare quartz phenocrysts (<1%, 0.2-0.5 mm) are commonly fragmented, probably related to quenching during eruption; i.e. explosive fragmentation ( Supplementary Fig. S3 ). The groundmass comprises microcrystalline quartz and feldspar, together with minor muscovite, biotite and rare hornblende (c. 60 μm). In some samples (e.g. nos. 14-19 and 14-20), the groundmass is cryptocrystalline, almost glassy ( Supplementary Fig. S3 ).

The basaltic rocks of both Late Cretaceous and Paleogene age generally fall into two groups in terms of mineral composition and texture. The first group (most common) is porphyritic with subhedral to euhedral clinopyroxene phenocrysts (30-40%), up to 0.6 mm long, that occur interstitially or are intergrown with subhedral feldspar (Supplementary Fig. S4 ). Feldspar (45-60%) forms elongate, acicular laths, up to 1 mm long. Olivine is relatively rare (<5%). The second group is ophitic, as locally observed in the western Kyrenia Range with abundant anhedral to subhedral augite phenocrysts (up to 0.6 mm in size). Most plagioclase is acicular, enclosed or surrounded by augite (Supplementary Fig. S4 ).

Most samples are slightly to moderately altered. Amygdales and veins are infilled with secondary minerals such as calcite and zeolite. Alteration is variable, for example, pyroxene and plagioclase are heavily altered to chlorite and clay minerals (e.g. smectite/sericite). The relatively high loss on ignition values result from secondary processes, which need to be taken into account prior to rock identification and tectonic discrimination.

Major-element oxides (K 2 O, Na 2 O and CaO) and trace elements (e.g. Rb, Sr and Ba) exhibit a relatively wide compositional range, consistent with the effects of alteration (see Supplementary Tables S1-S2) . Alteration can be inferred from variable LOI values that range between 0.3 and 5.4 wt% for the felsic volcanics and 4.09-14.57 wt% for the basaltic rocks. This is consistent with the presence of considerable amounts of water-and/or carbonate dioxide-bearing minerals, for example chlorite and calcite, as observed petrographically (see Supplementary Figs . S3, S4). Trace elements such as Ti, Zr, Y, Nb, Ta, V, Co, Th and REEs tend to be immobile during weathering and/or metamorphism below amphibole facies are, therefore, preferred for rock-type identification and tectonic discrimination (e.g. Pearce and Cann, 1973; Rollinson, 1993) . For basaltic rocks, samples with high crystal contents (cumulate composition or highly porphyritic) should be discounted from geochemical discrimination (Pearce, 1996) . In general, samples with immobile element Al 2 O 3 > 20 wt% (concentrated in feldspar), Sc > 50 ppm (concentrated in clinopyroxene), or Ni > 200 ppm (concentrated in olivine) are predicted to contain high amounts of accumulated minerals (Pearce, 1996) . On this basis, basaltic rocks nos. 14-66, 14-50, 14-51, 14-58, 14-68, 08, 16, 25 and 28 are discounted.

The more felsic assemblage is mainly rhyolitic in the classification of Winchester and Floyd (1977) but shows a trachytic affinity in the revised Zr/Ti vs. Nb/Y ( Fig. 6a ) diagram of Pearce (1996) . Relatively high abundances of Th (>14 ppm) but low Co concentrations (<12 ppm) are consistent with high-K and shoshonitic affinities (Fig. 6b ). Primitive mantle-normalised multi-element plots (Fig. 6c) show variable enrichments and depletions in large-ion lithophile elements (LILEs; e.g. Cs, Rb, Ba, K and Sr) that are influenced by alteration. The samples show negative anomalies of Nb, Zr and Ti, coupled with marked positive anomalies of Th/U, Pb, Nd and probably Sm (Fig. 6c ). Total REE contents of the felsic assemblage (Fourkovouno Formation) vary from 115 to 173 ppm. La ranges from 29 to 44 ppm, (La/Yb) N = 12.63-18.98, suggestive of an alkalic affinity. The ratios (La/Sm) N = 6.13-7.22 and (Gd/Yb) N = 1.26-1.68 suggest a large LREE fractionation but low to moderate HREE fractionation (Fig. 6d ). Pronounced negative Eu anomalies (Eu/ Eu* = 0.32-0.46) are consistent with plagioclase crystallization, as seen petrographically (see Supplementary Fig. S3 ). In general, the samples are comparable to upper continental crust (UCC).The basaltic rocks plot in the fields of basalt and alkali basalt, with intermediate degrees of fractionation (Zr/Ti = 0.01-0.02) and moderate alkalinity (Nb/Y = 0.1-1.8) on the rock-type discrimination plot (Fig. 7a) . The basalts have a calc-alkaline affinity, except for samples from Mallıdağ (no. 01), Tirmen (no. 19-51), Değirmenlik (no. 14-64) and İncesu (no. 19-67) that exhibit high-K and shoshonitic affinities (Fig. 7b) . The trace element compositions of the basaltic rocks exhibit wide ranges of Sr, Ba, Rb, Th, Ta, Nb and Ce. However, Zr, Hf, Sm, Ti and Y generally comparable with enriched mid-ocean ridge basalt (E-MORB) and oceanic island basalt (OIB) ( Fig. 8a-c) .

The basaltic rocks are characterised by variable REE concentrations (67.2-239.4 ppm) and light REE enrichments ((La/Yb) N = 2.26-19.35) ( Fig. 8d) . Samples from the central range, at Değirmenlik and Tirmen, show much higher total REE contents and steeper REE patterns. Westwards in the Kyrenia Range, the patterns become smoother, with less pronounced enrichment in LREEs. In general, no marked Eu anomaly (~1) is observed.

The selected basaltic samples have relatively uniform whole-rock Sr-Nd-Hf isotopic characteristics. Adopting a Late Cretaceous-Paleogene eruption age based on the paleontological dating (Robertson et al., 2012b) , the calculated initial 87 Sr/ 86 Sr ratios range from 0.705054 to 0.705701, with εNd(t) values of 2.27 to 5.76. Initial 176 Hf/ 177 Hf and εHf(t) values are 0.282934-0.283017, 7.36-10.14, respectively (see Supplementary Table S2 ).

Zircon crystals separated from the felsic rocks are typically angular to sub-angular, 30-160 μm long. The grains have variable internal textures, including banded zoning (e.g. zircon 1), concentric zoning (nos. 2, 4, 5 and 12), and minor sector zoning (nos. 10, 11; Fig. 9a ). Fractures (or depressions) and some inherited cores are affected by fluid-related chemical alteration (nos. 6 and 8) (Fig. 9a) . The zircon grains have high Th/U ratios (0.19-1.24), suggestive of a magmatic origin (Rubatto, 2002) . Twelve zircon grains were analysed with concordance levels ranging from 99 to 105%. The calculated 206 Pb/ 238 U age with the generally lowest possible error was used for age determination. The much older zircon grain (no. 4) is subhedral with a patchy xenocrystic texture, suggestive of a recycled origin (Fig. 9a) . The concordant or nearly concordant data (100-102%) yielded weighted mean 206 Pb/ 238 U gave ages of 74.0 ± 0.6 Ma, 74.0 ± 0.4 Ma and 71.7 ± 0.7 Ma ( Fig. 9b-d ).

For the felsic rocks, the high LREE/HREE (e.g. (La/Yb) N = 12.63-18.98) and negative Eu anomalies, resemble model UCC but with depletion in Eu, Sr and P ( Fig. 6c-d) . The A/CNK (molar ratio of Al 2 O 3 /(CaO + Na 2 O + K 2 O)) ratio is useful to identify the source of felsic rocks (Chappell and White, 1992) but is questionable for altered rocks like those of the Kyrenia Range. SiO 2 , P 2 O 5 and Th can also be used as indices of the fractional crystallization of a felsic melt (Chappell and White, 1992) , but again may be affected by alteration (specially SiO 2 ). In our samples, P 2 O 5 deceases with increasing SiO 2 and Th (Fig. 10a-b ), trends that are indicative of I (igneous)-or A (alkaline, anhydrous and anorogenic)-type granites. The relatively low contents of Zr, Nb, Y, La, Ce, Zn and Ga further characterise these rocks as I-type ( Fig. 10c-d) . The abundances of Th and Co, in particular hint at a shoshonitic composition (Hastie et al., 2007) .

The trace element patterns of the basaltic rocks show a wider range of variation (Fig. 8 ). E-MORB and OIB-type basalts were derived from relatively enriched sources, specifically for the basalts of the Karpas Peninsula, eastern range and most of the central range. The lesser enrichment of Nb within the basalts of the central range at Ergenekon (no. 31), Arapköy (no. 14-62) and Alevkaya Tepe (no. 14-49), and the western range at Karsıyaka (no. 14) and Geçitköy (no. 10), can be explained by a relatively depleted mantle source, together with subduction modification. There is little evidence of the addition of radiogenic Sr from seawater, either to the source melt or during post-magmatic alteration. The Nd vs. Sr isotope correlation diagram (Fig. 11a ) does not show a significant shift towards higher initial 87 Sr/ 86 Sr ratios as would be expected in both of these cases.

The basalts all have positive εNd(t) values (+2.27-+5.76), consistent with derivation from an OIB-like source mantle (Fig. 11a) . The samples plot directly on the terrestrial array, overlapping with the Nd isotope compositions of Etna and the Aeolian Arc, but intermediate between these settings in Hf isotopes (Fig. 11b) . The samples that show trace element evidence of a subduction-modified source, based on relatively flat MORB-normalised multi-element patterns and negative Nb anomalies (no. 10, Geçitköy), plot in the Aeolian Arc-type mantle field. Conversely, samples from the Karpas Peninsular, at Balalan, plot close to the field of Etna and exhibit less subduction modification (Fig. 11b) . The trace element and isotopic data, therefore, yield consistent results.

The involvement of a crustal component is also suggested by incompatible element ratio plots, on which the basalts exhibit two distinct trends. The samples with relatively strong subduction signatures plot away from the MORB array (Fig. 12a) , fingerprinting a subductionrelated lithospheric mantle end member. A probable lower crust input is suggested by relatively higher La/Nb and Ba/Nb ratios (e.g. Wang et al., 2004) . In contrast, an OIB-like mantle component dominated most of the other basalt samples, as indicated by relatively low La/Nb, Zr/Nb but high Nb/Y ratios (Fig. 12b) . The ratios of highly incompatible elements with small distribution coefficients (e.g. Zr/Nb, Nb/Th, Nb/La) are sensitive indicators of mantle source heterogeneity (Saunders et al., 1988; Condie, 2003; Pearce and Stern, 2006) . The samples from the western locations fall in the fields of an enriched component and upper continental crust (Fig. 12c) , which could represent mantle mixing with continental sediments (subducted) or crustal contamination. In contrast, the samples from the easterly locations resemble those of the OIB/recycled component, and cluster around a different batch-melting Zindler and Hart (1986) ; (b) εHf(t) vs. εNd(t) plot showing rocks for Kyrenia Range, northern Cyprus relative to other volcanic rocks of the western Mediterranean (after Kempton et al., 2018) . Abbreviations: DM, depleted mantle; EM, EMI and EMII, enriched mantle sources; OIB, oceanic island basalt; MORB, mid-ocean ridge basalt; HIMU, high mμ (U/Pb) source. trajectory (10-20%) (Fig. 12c ) that is representative of recycled oceanic lithosphere (Saunders et al., 1988) . We, therefore, infer that the basalts are likely to have been derived from multiple sources (i.e. two or more source components were involved).

On the Nb vs.Y diagram (Fig. 13a ), the felsic volcanics show similarities with volcanic arc granites and syn-collisional granites. One sample from Geçitköy (no. 16-08), with relatively high Nb and Y concentrations, plots near the field of within-plate granite. On the Th/Yb vs. Ta/ Yb diagram (Fig. 13b) , the volcanics mainly fall in the active continental margins field. An active continental margin setting is therefore inferred for the felsic volcanics.

Basalts of the Kyrenia Range (e.g. easterly locations) mostly exhibit a within-plate affinity (Fig. 8) . However, some samples, especially in the west, have a subduction-related signature (e.g. negative Nb anomalies) ( Fig. 8b-c) akin to volcanic arc basalts. Most samples have a within-plate affinity on the Zr/Y vs. Zr (Fig. 13c) diagram, except for two samples, from Ergenekon and Arapköy (central range), that straddle the island arc and MORB fields. The basalts overlap the MORB and back-arc basin basalt fields on the Ti vs. V plot (Fig. 13d ). Clinopyroxene compositions, as shown in the ternary TiO 2 -MnO-Na 2 O plot (see Supplementary  Fig. S5 ), indicate a dominantly within-plate affinity. The relatively high TiO 2 contents of the clinopyroxenes point to an enriched MORBrelated source (see Supplementary Fig. S5 ). Overall, the inferred subduction contribution decreases from west to east along the range.

Global comparisons (see Supplementary Fig. S6 ) lend support to our interpretation of the Kyrenia Range volcanic rocks as being subductionrelated. In particular, within the Late Cretaceous felsic rocks, the enrichment of Rb, Th and Sm versus the depletion of Ti, Ba, Nb, P compared to primitive mantle, are characteristic of volcanic arc granites (Fig. 6c ) (Pearce et al., 1984) .
body_text.section: Global comparison of the Kyrenia Range volcanic rocks

body_text.text: The Kyrenia Range Maastrichtian and Paleogene basalts of withinplate affinities (e.g. Balalan, eastern range) mainly have MORBnormalised spider patterns that are similar to the Pliocene-Quaternary OIB-type basalts of the Tyrrhenian Sea, W Mediterranean (Peccerillo, 2017) . The MORB-normalised patterns of these basalts suggest a within-plate eruptive setting, with a small sub-crustal lithosphere metasomatic influence (Peccerillo, 2017) .
body_text.section: Global comparison of the Kyrenia Range volcanic rocks

body_text.text: Back-arc basalts of the Early Cretaceous Sarmiento Complex, southern Chile (Saunders et al., 1979) and the Miocene Japan Sea (Tamaki et al., 1990 ) resemble a minority of the Kyrenia Range basalts (c. 10%; e.g. Geçitköy, western range), although with lower abundances of K, Rb, Ba, Th, Ta and Nb. The relative depletion of these elements is characteristic of eruption in a relatively wide, evolved back-arc basin (e.g. Bransfield Strait; Weaver et al., 1979) . However, another possible setting is eruption in a back-arc basin that was influenced by oblique extension (e.g. Guaymas pull-apart basin; Brune et al., 2012) . The relatively flat MORB-normalised patterns, akin to E-MORB, of both the Bransfield Strait and Guaymas back-arc basin basalts (e.g. Keller et al., 2002; Saunders et al., 1982) point to substantial involvement of depleted MORB sources.
body_text.section: Global comparison of the Kyrenia Range volcanic rocks

body_text.text: Late Cretaceous and Paleogene arc-related rocks; i.e. similar in age of those in the Kyrenia Range are critical to any regional magmatictectonic interpretation.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: In western Cyprus, a Late Cretaceous arc-derived volcanogenic succession (Kannaviou Formation) overlies the Troodos ophiolite. The volcaniclastic sediments were derived from intermediate-felsic eruptions, c. 6 Ma before the felsic eruptions in the Kyrenia Range (c. 80 vs. 74 Ma). Grain size and textural evidence suggest that, depending on prevailing wind direction and strength, the eruptive centers are likely to have been <100 km away (Chen and Robertson, 2019) . The centers for the Kannaviou Formation were located to the south of the Kyrenia Range or its lateral extension, areas that are not now exposed. The Kyrenia Range was affected by south-directed thrusting during Mid-Eocene and Late Miocene-earliest Pliocene (Baroz, 1979; Robertson et al., 2012b Robertson et al., , 2014 McCay and Robertson, 2013; Robertson and Kinnaird, 2016) , such that the distal (southerly) edge of the inferred over-riding active margin (see below) could have been subducted, structurally over-ridden or eroded. In other words, additional arc units could have existed to the south of their present location in the Kyrenia Range.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: To the northeast (c. 200 km), the Misis-Andırın Range in southern Turkey is an extension of the Kyrenia lineament (Robertson et al., 2004) . The outcrop, known as the Misis-Andırın Complex, includes massive basalts, pillow lavas, lava breccias and volcaniclastic debris-flows. These lithologies were previously inferred to be Miocene (Floyd et al., 1991 (Floyd et al., , 1992 . However, inter-lava sediments there have been dated as Campanian-Maastrichtian (Robertson et al., 2004) , similar in age to the oldest basaltic rocks in the Kyrenia Range. The Miocene sediments are structurally intercalated. The basalts of the Misis-Andırın Complex are tholeiitic, with mildly enriched, subduction-related characteristics (e.g. moderate La/Nb ratios), and are interpreted as of back-arc basin origin (Floyd et al., 1991 (Floyd et al., , 1992 , which is consistent with our interpretation of the Kyrenia Range basalts (Fig. 14a-b, Supplementary Fig. S6 ). (Pearce et al., 1984) and (b) Th/Yb vs. Ta/Yb (Gorton and Schandl, 2000) for the felsic volcanics; (c) Zr/Y vs. Zr diagram (after Pearce and Norry, 1979) and (d) V vs. Ti discrimination diagram (after Shervais, 1982) for the basaltic rocks. Abbreviations: WPG, within-plate granite; VAG, volcanic arc granite; syn-COLG, syn-collisional granite; ORG, ocean ridge granite; WPB, within-plate basalt; MORB, mid-ocean ridge basalt; BABB, back-arc basin basalt; ARC, arc-related basalt; OFB, oceanic floor basalt.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: The Kyrenia Range is backed to the north by the Alanya Massif (Fig. 1) , which has been interpreted as a continental fragment, separate from the Tauride carbonate platform to the north (Çetinkaplan et al., 2016; Robertson et al., 2012a) . The Alanya Massif is represented by the Late Precambrian-Mesozoic, mainly meta-sedimentary rocks. High pressure-low temperature (HP-LT) metamorphic rocks document Late Cretaceous (82-80 Ma) subduction/exhumation (Oberhänsli et al., 2010 (Oberhänsli et al., , 2013 . This is inferred to have taken place along the northern, active margin of the Southern Neotethys (Çetinkaplan et al., 2016; . The felsic volcanics (Fourkovouno Formation) in the Kyrenia Range could have erupted along the southern (trailing) margin of the Alanya microcontinent where they could have escaped metamorphism. However, they could also represent a separate more southerly unit.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: Late Cretaceous continental margin arc-type magmatic rocks also occur extensively farther east, in SE Turkey, as two separate belts.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: The most southerly, known Late Cretaceous arc rocks in SE Turkey are exposed in the Helete area, part of a zone of frontal thrust sheets (Nurlu et al., 2016; Yıldırım, 2015) (Fig. 1) . Two thrust assemblages are exposed, both cut by granites that have been radiometrically dated at 93-83 Ma (Cenomanian-Campanian) (Nurlu et al., 2016) . The lower of the assemblages, the Helete volcanics, comprises arc-related basaltic andesite, andesite, dacite, rhyolite and common tuffaceous rocks. The upper of the two thrust assemblages is a dismembered Late Cretaceous supra-subduction zone-type ophiolite (Meydan ophiolite) (Nurlu et al., 2016; Yıldırım, 2015) . The cross-cutting intrusive rocks sealed the thrust sheets during the Late Cretaceous. The granitic rocks are interpreted as a calc-alkaline, subduction-related suite that formed by mixing of mantle and crustal sources, as suggested by Sr-Nd-Pb isotopic data (Nurlu et al., 2016) . The granitic rocks exhibit relatively flat chondrite-normalised REE patterns, similar to E-MORB (Nurlu et al., 2016 ) ( Supplementary Fig. S6 ). In contrast, the chondrite-normalised REE patterns of the Kyrenia Range felsic rocks are similar to UCC (Fig. 6c ), suggesting a more continentally-influenced setting.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: The second belt of arc-related magmatism is located up to c. 100 km farther north and north-east, in the Keban (Malatya), Göksun (Kahramanmaraş) and Baskil (Elazığ) regions (Fig. 1) (Karaoğlan et al., 2013 (Karaoğlan et al., , 2016 Parlak, 2006; Rızaoğlu et al., 2009; Yazgan and Chessex, 1991) . Arc-granitic rocks (Baskil intrusives) cut the Late Cretaceous Göksun ophiolite and equivalents (i.e. Berit meta-ophiolite (=North Berit ophiolite) (Yılmaz et al., 1993) , Kömürhan ophiolite and İspendere ophiolite) that are inferred to have formed above a northward-dipping subduction zone (Parlak, 2006) . Similar arc granites also cut the structurally over-riding Malayta metamorphic unit, which is interpreted as the southern part of the Tauride microcontinent. The Göksun ophiolite (and equivalents) and the Malayta metamorphic (Tauride) units were juxtaposed along an active continental margin when the arc-granitic rocks were intruded (Karaoğlan et al., 2013 (Karaoğlan et al., , 2016 Rızaoğlu et al., 2009; Robertson et al., 2006) .
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: The extrusive rocks of the Göksun and related ophiolites can also be broadly correlated with widespread assemblages of basic igneous rocks and volcanogenic sediments in the Malatya-Elazığ region, known as the Yüksekova Complex (Aktaş and Robertson, 1984; Perinçek and Özkaya, 1981) . The basalts have a tholeiitic to tholeiitic-transitional character, variable Zr/Y (1.5-6) ratios and mantle-array-aligned Sr-Nd isotopes (Ural et al., 2015) . These basic volcanics were derived from a depleted mantle source without a significant crustal contribution; i.e. from an intra-oceanic setting within the Southern Neotethys (Ural et al., 2015) .
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: The arc rocks that cut both the Göksun (and related) ophiolites and the Malatya Metamorphics (Baskil intrusives) in the northern belt are mainly hornblende-biotite granodiorites and 'normal' granites, dated radiometrically at 88-82 Ma (Santonian-Campanian) (Karaoğlan et al., 2016 : Parlak, 2006 Rızaoğlu et al., 2009) ; i.e. up to c. 5 Ma younger than Helete area granites in the south. These southerly granitic rocks have I-type, calc-alkaline arc affinities, with both mantle and crustalderivation features (Nurlu et al., 2016) . The Baskil intrusions of the northern belt are relatively enriched in LREE (Parlak, 2006; Rızaoğlu et al., 2009) compared to the Helete granites of the south, which suggests a more crustally influenced source during magma genesis for the former. Similarly, the Kyrenia Range basalts have relatively high Zr/Y (2.8-7.7) and Nb/Y (Figs. 12b, 13c ), suggestive of a magmatic contribution from continental crust or subducted continentally derived sediments (Pearce, 1996; Zindler and Hart, 1986) .
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: The northerly arc has been explained by northward subduction of a Mesozoic oceanic basin (Berit ocean) that was located between two continental units; i.e. the Bitlis and Püturge massifs in the south and the Tauride continent represented by the Malatya Metamorphics in the north (Barrier et al., 2018; Karaoğlan et al., 2013 Karaoğlan et al., , 2016 Robertson et al., 2012a) . The Late Cretaceous arc-related intrusive magmatism of the northern belt in SE Turkey (Baskil intrusives) evolved towards collisional, including shoshonitic, compositions (74-72 Ma), which are interpreted to indicate continental and post-collisional settings (Erturk et al., 2018; Kuşcu et al., 2013; Sar et al., 2019) . The shoshonitic compositions of some of the granitic rocks, together with the evidence Floyd et al., 1991) . Abbreviations: IAT, island arc tholeiite; BABB, back-arc basin basalt; OFB, oceanic flood basalt; FAPB, fore-arc platform basalt; T/E-MORB, T-type/enriched mid-ocean ridge basalt.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: of HP/LT metamorphism, are consistent with the collision of the Tauride carbonate platform (i.e. Malatya Metamorphics) to the north with the Bitlis and Pütürge continental units to the south. However, the origins of shoshonites remain controversial because the necessary partial melting of mantle and interaction with subduction-related fluids can take place in a variety of pre-, syn-and post-collisional settings (e.g. Campbell et al., 2014) .
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: Several authors have correlated the Late Cretaceous Göksun and related ophiolites in the north with the Meydan ophiolite (Berit metaophiolite of Yılmaz et al., 1993) in the south. If correct, the granitic intrusives in both belts originated as different parts of a single arc lineament that straddled the northerly active continental margin of the oceanic basin. The southerly arc and ophiolitic rocks (Helete-Meydan) were emplaced southwards during the latest Cretaceous, although further southward thrusting took place, mainly during the Eocene and Miocene (Perinçek and Kozlu, 1984; Yılmaz et al., 1993) .
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: In many reconstructions, oceanic crust still remained between the Bitlis-Püturge continental units and Arabia until the Miocene (Barrier et al., 2018; Robertson et al., 2012a; van Hinsbergen et al., 2020; Yılmaz, 1993) . The Bitlis and Püturge massifs have been generally correlated with the Alanya metamorphic massif to the north of Cyprus (with or without a direct continuation) (Çetinkaplan et al., 2016) . If correct, the Late Cretaceous Kyrenia Range felsic arc volcanism (and that of the Kannaviou Formation) could have been located to south of the Alanya continent, with a possible eastward continuation to south of the Bitlis and Püturge continental units.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: Paleogene magmatic rocks are also present in SE Turkey. Eocene volcanic rocks and associated minor intrusions, known as the Maden Complex, unconformably overlie and cut the Pütürge and Bitlis metamorphosed continental units (Fig. 1) Robertson, 1984, 1990; Elmas and Yılmaz, 2003; Erturk et al., 2018; Hempton, 1985; Robertson et al., 2006; Yazgan and Chessex, 1991; Yılmaz, 1993) . The volcanics show enrichment in LILEs and relative depletion in Nb, Ta and Ti compared to MORB (Erturk et al., 2018) , similar to a minority of the subduction-related volcanics in the Kyrenia Range (see Supplementary  Fig. S6 ). The Eocene Maden Complex magmatism is widely proposed to relate to back-arc rifting of the (Eurasian) active continental margin during the later stages of northward subduction of the Southern Neotethys, in keeping with the widespread view that collision with Arabia was delayed until the Miocene Robertson, 1984, 1990; Robertson et al., 2006 Robertson et al., , 2007 van Hinsbergen et al., 2020; Yiğitbaş and Yılmaz, 1996; Yılmaz, 1993; Yılmaz et al., 1993) . Oblique convergence, proposed by several authors (Aktaş and Robertson, 1990; Elmas and Yılmaz, 2003) , could have resulted in along-strike variation in the geochemical signatures of extension versus subduction in the Kyrenia Range, although more geochemical work is needed, regionally and globally to test this hypothesis.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: Farther north, Eocene granitic rocks locally cut the continental Malatya metamorphic unit (Doğanşehir region) (Karaoğlan et al., 2013 (Karaoğlan et al., , 2016 Perinçek and Kozlu, 1984) . However, no extrusive equivalents are known and, as noted above, the magmatic rocks in this lineament are unlikely to correlate directly with the Kyrenia Range.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: During the Miocene, the active continental margin bordering the remnant Southern Neotethys collided with the Arabian passive continental margin to the south. In both the Kyrenia Range and SE Turkey, the Late Cretaceous and Paleogene magmatic rocks are exposed close the thrust front (Eurasia), implying that at least tens of kms of fore-arc crust have been lost (subducted or overridden), potentially removing additional frontal arc-related crust, both Late Cretaceous and Paleogene. Thus, the Kyrenia Range, Kannaviou Formation (W Cyprus) and Maden Complex magmatism could all represent surviving products of a regional active continental margin.
body_text.section: Comparison with the adjacent Tethyan region

body_text.text: In the light of the regional setting, the felsic volcanics (Fourkovouno Formation, c. 74 Ma), with continental margin arc affinities, are interpreted to have resulted from northward subduction beneath continental crust, possibly the Alanya continental unit to the north (Çetinkaplan et al., 2016; . The felsic volcanism is characteristic of relatively advanced subduction, suggesting that earlier eruptive centers existed along the active continental margin. The early volcanism is likely to be represented by the Campanian (c. 80 Ma) arc-derived volcanogenic sediments (Kannaviou Formation) in western Cyprus (Chen and Robertson, 2019; Gilbert and Robertson, 2013; Robertson, 1977) . The underlying mantle wedge (sub-continental lithosphere) was metasomatically enriched during the Late Cretaceous subduction, with implications for the subsequent basaltic volcanism.

For the Maastrichtian to Late Eocene basaltic volcanics, there are three alternative tectono-magmatic models. The first model envisages a marginal basin setting related to northward subduction. Compared to typical back-arc basin basalts (Fig. 14a-b) , the Kyrenia Range basalts have relatively high Th/Nb but low La/Nb ratios. The high abundances of Th are likely to reflect a continental crust influence (Floyd et al., 1991) . The variation in La/Nb ratios of the basalts could reflect the influence of a within-plate mantle source (i.e. easterly basalts) and/or the arc maturity; i.e. the arc-like western basalts could have erupted closer to the distal (oceanward) edge of the convergent margin. However, a problem with this model is the absence of evidence for a Paleogene volcanic arc to the south. There is no evidence of arc-derived fallout tuff or volcaniclastic sediments in the Maastrichtian-Paleogene basaltic succession, in contrast with, for example, the SW Pacific Mariana and Tonga marginal basins (Bryan et al., 2004; Clift, 1994 ).

The second model involves an extensional (or transtensional) setting. In this interpretation, the Late Maastrichtian and Paleogene 'enriched' within-plate volcanism was triggered by strike-slip (or transtension) along the active continental margin. One option is that the volcanism was linked to the anticlockwise paleorotation of the Troodos ophiolite to the south during Late Campanian-Early Eocene (Clube et al., 1985; Clube and Robertson, 1986; Hodgson et al., 2010; Morris et al., 2006 Morris et al., , 2015 . More generally, oblique convergence of the African plate with respect to Eurasia could have resulted in segmentation of the South Neotethyan active margin into subducting segments with arc magmatism, and other strike-slip segments without arc magmatism (Aktaş and Robertson, 1990) . A modern example is the Andaman Sea where oblique convergence between the Asian and the Australian plates resulted in segmented arc magmatism (e.g. Curray, 2005) . However, there is limited information from different modern settings to test this hypothesis.

The third, preferred, scenario is that both the felsic and the basaltic volcanism are related to northward subduction during stages in the closure of the Mesozoic ocean basin to the south. The Late Cretaceous magmatism can then be explained by regional northward subduction (nearly orthogonal) resulting in continental margin arc volcanism. Slab-derived and residual slab components (fluid, melt) were released into the upper mantle lithosphere (e.g. Harangi et al., 2007; Pearce, 1983) . The Late Maastrichtian and Paleogene basaltic volcanics then erupted in an extensional (or transtensional) setting, perhaps related to slab rollback and incipient marginal basin formation. Several different mantle sources are likely to have contributed along the Kyrenia Range. The variable subductionrelated signatures were inherited from the previously modified mantle lithosphere in this interpretation. Examples of subductioninfluenced settings that were affected by later extension-related melting include the Rio Grande Rift, west USA (e.g. Riecker, 1979) and the Neogene north Aegean-west Anatolia volcanic province (e.g. Ersoy and Palmer, 2013; Şengör and Yılmaz, 1981) . In summary, the available evidence is consistent with Late Maastrichtian-Paleogene incipient marginal basin formation along the northern, active margin of an ocean basin (Southern Neotethys) that did not close until the Miocene.

Finally, the Late Cretaceous-Paleogene volcanism in N Cyprus and SE Turkey can be used to test alternative plate tectonic models, including those by Robertson et al. (2012a) , Karaoğlan et al. (2013 Karaoğlan et al. ( , 2016 , Maffione et al. (2017) , Barrier et al. (2018) , McPhee and van Hinsbergen (2019) and van Hinsbergen et al. (2020) , as summarised in Fig. 15 .

In Reconstruction 1 (Fig. 15a-c) (Robertson et al., 2012a) , the Southern Neotethys rifted in the Triassic, while Paleotethys evolved into the Northern Neotethys (İzmir-Ankara-Erzincan ocean). The Kyrenia Range is restored to the northern passive margin of the Southern Neotethys. Both intra-oceanic and continental margin subduction zones (northward-dipping) were active in the Southern Neotethys during the Late Cretaceous. The continental margin arc volcanism was constructed on, or to the south of one, or more, continental blocks (microcontinents), represented by the Kyrenia-Alanya-Püturge-Bitlis lineament in the south and the Malatya-Keban lineament farther north. This reconstruction is compatible with our new evidence.

Reconstruction 2 (Fig. 15d-f ) (Barrier et al., 2018) has many common features with (1), in particular the arc volcanism along the northern margin of the Southern Neotethys. However, the Kyrenia, Malatya and Pütürge-Bitlis massifs are restored as a single elongate continental unit rather than as microcontinents, as in (1). Also, little or no oceanic crust is inferred between the southerly continental unit and the Tauride carbonate platform to the north (i.e. Göksun and related ophiolites). This is difficult to reconcile with the Late Cretaceous and Eocene granitic magmatism cutting the Mesozoic Malatya (Keban) platform unless large-scale strike-slip and terrane duplication has taken place for which there is little supporting evidence.

In Reconstruction 3 ( Fig. 15g-h) (Maffione et al., 2017; van Hinsbergen et al., 2020) , the Kyrenia Range is restored to the southern passive margin of the Mesozoic Tethyan ocean. Late Cretaceous ophiolites that are presently located in several c. E-W, sub-parallel belts (i.e. N and S of the Bitlis and Pütürge massifs) originated above a single subduction zone within Neotethys, dipping generally to the east or northeast (Moix et al., 2008; Stampfli and Borel, 2002) . The subduction zone rolled back generally westwards until it collided with the Tauride and Arabian continents. In the south, the subduction zone broke through an oceanic gap between the African and Tauride continents, 'invaded' and replaced the Southern Neotethys with Late Cretaceous suprasubduction zone fore-arc crust. Fore-arc ophiolites were then obducted generally northwards and southwards over the opposing continents (van Hinsbergen et al., 2020) . Two alternatives are suggested; in one, Fig. 15 . Alternative tectonic models of Tethys in the Eastern Mediterranean region. (a-c) Northward subduction with continental fragments rifted from Gondwana (Robertson et al., 2012a) ; (d-f) Northward subduction and marginal basin formation (Barrier et al., 2018) ; (g-h) Genesis of Late Cretaceous supra-subduction ophiolites at a single subduction zone to the NE followed by roll-back of segments including the Southern Neotethys (Maffione et al., 2017; McPhee and van Hinsbergen, 2019; van Hinsbergen et al., 2020). Based on discussion (see text), model 1 is generally favoured.

the Bitlis and Pütürge continental units are correlated with Arabia (Maffione et al., 2017) , whereas in the other, these units are correlated with the southern margin of the Tauride continent (van Hinsbergen et al., 2020) . The Kyrenia Range (Trypa Group) is placed on the N African continental margin in both alternatives. The metamorphism of the Mesozoic carbonate platform in the Kyrenia Range (Trypa Group) resulted from northeastward underthrusting/subduction beneath the obducted forearc Troodos ophiolite (van Hinsbergen et al., 2020) . However, there are several problematic aspects: (1) seismic tomography in the Eastern Mediterranean supports generally northward subduction (e.g. Hafkenscheid et al., 2006) , without evidence of a relict southwarddipping slab, as implied by the inferred northward emplacement of some Late Cretaceous ophiolites in S Turkey; (2) it does not allow for the tens to hundreds of km of subduction required to produce the Late Cretaceous arc magmatism in N Cyprus and SE Turkey;

(3) the model (van Hinsbergen et al., 2020) does not allow for any Late Cretaceous continental arc-related magmatism in northern Cyprus, SE Turkey or Iran (e.g. Agard et al., 2011) ; (4) the proposed Late Eocene-Miocene (post 45 Ma) northward subduction is too young to explain the Late Cretaceous-Paleogene magmatic rocks in the Kyrenia Range and SE Turkey; (5) arc magmatism of Oligocene-Miocene age in S Turkey is absent, although this would be expected if significant northward subduction took place during this time, as in model 3.

• Latest Cretaceous mainly felsic volcanic rocks and latest Cretaceous-Paleogene mainly basaltic volcanic rocks are exposed throughout the Kyrenia Range, separated by a thrust. • Mapping and logging of the key, well-exposed western Kyrenia Range segment shows that the Late Cretaceous felsic arc volcanics occur as variably dismembered thrust sheets in the southerly, frontal part of thrust belt. • The primary eruptive age of the felsic arc volcanics (Fourkovouno Formation) is c. 74.0 Ma (Late Campanian), based on U-Pb dating of zircons. • The latest Cretaceous-Paleogene basalts vary geochemically along the Kyrenia Range (E-W). The volcanics in the east resemble normal rift products. In contrast, the volcanics in the west have a subordinate subduction-related signature (e.g. negative Nb anomaly). • Sr-Nd-Hf isotopic data for the latest Cretaceous-Paleogene basalts suggest that they were derived from several OIB-like mantle sources, with the involvement of a crustally-derived (recycled) component. • The Kyrenia Range felsic volcanics show some geochemical similarities with the late Cretaceous arc-related rocks in S Turkey (Helete granite; 93-83 Ma). These felsic volcanics are interpreted to represent a fragment of a mature magmatic arc that was active along a regional-scale active continental margin. Regional reconstructions suggest that the Helete granites and related ophiolitic rocks were emplaced southwards from an oceanic basin (Berit ocean) to the north. FIGREF1.text: (a) A-A′ Cross section of Geçitköy that is dominated by a south-verging, recumbent anticline (Late Miocene-earliest Pliocene); (b) B-B′ Cross-section of Selvilitepe showing southward imbrication of basalt/pelagic chalk and felsic volcanogenic rocks; (c) C-C′ Cross-section showing imbricated felsic volcanogenic rocks.

FIGREF2.text: Fig. 5. Measured stratigraphic logs of partial successions in the felsic volcanics and structurally associated units. The structural lower unit (logs a-e) is relatively intact, whereas the higher unit (logs f-j) is characterised by thrust intercalations with the Trypa Group.

FIGREF3.text: (a) Zr/Ti vs. Nb/Y diagram (afterPearce, 1996) and (b) Th vs. Co diagram (afterHastie et al., 2007) for the Kyrenia Range felsic rocks; (c) Primitive mantle-normalised multi-element spider diagram and (d) Chondrite-normalised rare earth element (REE) patterns of the felsic volcanics with reference data for upper continental crust (UCC) and lower continental crust (LCC). Normalising values of primitive mantle and chondrite afterSun and McDonough (1989); data of upper continental crust (UCC) and lower continental crust (LCC) are fromRudnick and Gao (2003), andHu and Gao (2008). The Chile volcanic arc granite data are afterPearce et al. (1984).

FIGREF4.text: (a) Zr/Ti vs. Nb/Y diagram (afterPearce, 1996) and (b) Th vs. Co diagram (afterHastie et al., 2007) for the basaltic volcanics. Red symbols: Karpas Peninsula and eastern range; green symbols: central range; blue symbols: western range. Paleogene basalt samples are indicated by thick magenta-outlined symbols.

FIGREF5.text: Mid-ocean ridge basalt (MORB)-normalised multi-element spider diagram for basalts from the Karpas Peninsula and the eastern (a), central (b) and western (c) Kyrenia Range. MORB-normalised data are fromPearce (1983); (d) Chondrite-normalised REE patterns of selected basalts. Chondrite, OIB and E-MORB data are fromSun and McDonough (1989). Paleogene basalt samples are indicated by solid black lines and magenta-outlined symbols.

FIGREF6.text: (a) Cathodoluminescence images of zircon grains separated from the samples of Geçitköy. Red circles mark inconsistent analyses that were omitted from the weighted mean 206 Pb/ 238 U age calculation. Locations of the ion probe analysis spots and the corresponding ages ( 206 Pb/ 238 U ± 1σ) are indicated. Scale bar = 20 μm; (b-d) Wetherill Concordia diagram for the zircons analyses from sample 14-18 (b), 14-19 (c) and 14-20 (d).

FIGREF7.text: (a-b) Plots of P 2 O 5 vs. SiO 2 and Th, respectively, show that all of the samples follow the I-type granite trend; (c) Zr vs. 10,000 × Ga/Al, and (d) Nb vs. 10,000 × Ga/Al discrimination diagrams ofWhalen et al. (1987), showing the I-, S (sedimentary)-and M (depleted mantle source)-type nature of the Late Cretaceous felsic volcanics.

FIGREF8.text: (a) εNd(t) vs. εSr(t) diagram for the basaltic rocks analysed. The samples are mainly Late Cretaceous (n = 4); Paleogene basalt samples (n = 2) are indicated by magenta-outlined symbols. Comparative compositions are from

FIGREF9.text: (a) Ba/Nb versus La/Nb diagram (afterZhang et al., 2013); (b) Nb/Y versus Zr/Y diagram (afterCondie, 2005), the arrows in (b) indicate the effects of batch melting (F) and the probable effect of fluids derived from subduction (SUB); (c) Zr/Nb vs. Nb/Th diagram (modified afterCondie, 2003). Abbreviations: PM, primitive mantle; DM, shallow depleted mantle; HIMU, high mμ (U/Pb) source; EMI and EMII, enriched mantle sources; ARC, arc-related basalt; N-MORB, normal mid-ocean ridge basalt; OIB, oceanic island basalt; DEP, deep depleted mantle; EN, enriched component; REC, recycled component; UCC, upper continental crust; LCC, lower continental crust; BM, batch melting trajectory with percent melting noted. Numbers on mixing lines are percents.

FIGREF12.text: The latest Cretaceous-Paleogene volcanics in the Kyrenia Range have geochemical similarities with the Middle Eocene (c. 47 Ma) basaltic rocks in S Turkey (Maden Complex), suggesting an along-strike continuation of the same active continental margin.• The latest Cretaceous-Paleogene basaltic volcanics in the Kyrenia Range are interpreted as the products of an incipient marginal basin that developed during northward subduction, possibly related to oblique convergence, prior to collision with Arabia during the Miocene. • In the light of alternative regional tectonic models, the Late Cretaceous and Paleogene magmatic rocks of N Cyprus are interpreted to represent stages in the development of the northerly active continental margin of the Southern Neotethys.
